article.title: Transport_in_Chad
article.paragraph: Transport infrastructure withinChadis generally poor, especially in the north and east of the country. River transport is limited to the south-west corner. As of 2011 Chad had no railways though two lines are planned - from the capital to the Sudanese and Cameroonian borders.citation neededAugust 2012

Roads are mostly unsurfaced and are likely to be impassable during thewet season, especially in the southern half of the country. In the north, roads are merely tracks across thedesertandland minescontinue to present a danger. Draft animals (horses,donkeysandcamels) remain important in much of the country.citation neededAugust 2012
Fuel supplies can be erratic, even in the south-west of the country, and are expensive. Elsewhere they are practically non-existent.citation neededAugust 2012

article.heading: Railways
article.paragraph: mainRail transport in ChadAs of 2011 Chad had no railways. Two lines are planned to Sudan and Cameroon from the capital, with construction expected to start in 2012.cite webhttp://www.railwaygazette.com/nc/news/single-view/view/work-to-begin-on-chad-rail-network/archiv/2012/01.html Work to begin on Chad rail network www.railwaygazette.com [[Railway Gazette International]] 13 January 2012
article.heading: Highways
article.paragraph: Chad has a total of 33,400 km of roads of which approximately 500 km are paved. Some, but not all of the roads in the capitalN'Djamenaare paved. Outside of N'Djamena there is one paved road which runs fromMassakoryin the north, through N'Djamena and then south, through the cities ofGuelendeng,Bongor,Klo, ChadKloandMoundou, with a short spur leading in the direction ofKousseri, Cameroon, near N'Djamena. Expansion of the road towards Cameroon throughPala, ChadPalaandLr, ChadLris reportedly in the preparatory stages.citation neededAugust 2012
article.heading: Waterways
article.paragraph: Most rivers flow but intermittently. On theChari RiverChari, between NDjamena andLake Chad, transportation is possible all year round. In September and October, theLogone RiverLogoneis navigable between NDjamena andMoundou, and theChari RiverCharibetween NDjamena and Sarh. Total waterways cover 4,800 km (3,000 mi), of which 2,000 km (1,250 mi) are navigable all year.citation neededAugust 2012
Chari and Logone Rivers are navigable only in wet season (2002). Both flow northwards, from the south of Chad, intoLake Chad.citation neededAugust 2012
article.heading: Pipelines
article.paragraph: Since 2003, a 1,070 km pipeline has been used to exportcrude oilfrom theoilfieldsaroundDoba, ChadDobato offshore oil-loading facilities onCameroon'sAtlantic oceanAtlanticcoast atKribi.cite webhttp://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/COUNTRIES/AFRICAEXT/EXTREGINI/EXTCHADCAMPIPELINE/0,,contentMDK:20516071~menuPK:843292~pagePK:64168445~piPK:64168309~theSitePK:843238,00.html Chad-Cameroon Pipeline: Project Overview The World Bank Group http://web.archive.org/web/20060326081220/http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/COUNTRIES/AFRICAEXT/EXTREGINI/EXTCHADCAMPIPELINE/0,,contentMDK:20516071~menuPK:843292~pagePK:64168445~piPK:64168309~theSitePK:843238,00.html 26 March 2006
article.heading: Seaports and harbors
article.paragraph: Chad's main routes to the sea are:citation neededAugust 2012

list.listitem: FromN'Djamenaand the south west of Chad:By road toNgaoundr, in Cameroon, and then by rail toDoualaBy road toMaiduguri, inNigeria, and then by rail toPort Harcourt
From the north and east of Chad:By road across theSaharadesert toLibya

article.paragraph: In colonial times, the main access was by road toBangui, in theCentral African Republic, then by river boat toBrazzaville, and onwards by rail from Brazzaville toPointe Noire, onRepublic of CongoCongo'sAtlanticcoast. This route is now little used.citation neededAugust 2012
There is also a route acrossSudan, to theRed Sea, but very little trade goes this way.citation neededAugust 2012
Links withNiger, north of Lake Chad, are practically nonexistent; it is easier to reach Niger via Cameroon and Nigeria.citation neededAugust 2012
article.heading: Airports
article.paragraph: As of2012Chad had an estimated 58 airports, only 9 of which had paved runways.cite webhttps://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/cd.html Chad:Transport [[The World Factbook]] [[CIA]] 15 August 2012Air Tchad(60 percent state owned) provides internal service to 12 locations but suffers from lack of fuel and equipment. The international airport at NDjamena was damaged in fighting in 1981, but is now served by several international carriers includingAir Afrique, which is partly owned by Chad. Another major airport, developed as a military staging area, is located atSarh. In 2003, scheduled airlines in Chad carried about 46,000 passengers on domestic and international flights.citation neededAugust 2012
